label: Letter from Sidney Jennings Legendre, January 1, 1945
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, regarding the news he has heard of his sister and brother-in-law, Jane Sanford Pansa and Mario Pansa, discussing the business aspects of running Medway Plantation, and praising their family friend, Polly, for how generous she is to their family. This letter was written to Gertrude when she was a prisoner of war in Europe and was likely to have been received in the package that was given to her upon her escape and return to the continental United States.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Letter 13
Mrs Gertrude Legendre,
1st. Lt WAC
US Prisoner of War in Germany
c International Committe of the Red Cross January 1, 1945
Geneva, Switzerland.
Gertie Darling,
The first day of the new year and I feel that it
is a year full of happiness and promise. I feel that you
will be released soon and will be back in the states. Why
I should feel this is quite be ond me as I have he rd nothing
about you at all. It may be a premonition or just because
I want it to happen so much.
The New York Office forwarded me copies of letters
received from Janie and her husband. I could not believe my
eyes as I read about the polo, he is president of the club.
The long discussion of the relative merits of the ponies, the
dinners and who they had seen. How impossible it was to
remember anyones name because one saw so many people. A
short sentence saying that no doubt the poor people are having
a difficult time buying food and then a paragraph about you.
I kept beth of these letters because I think they will give
you a great kick and also they should become part of history.
I wonder if the writers or the recipients wondered at
themselves and considered what they were saying and doing
while the entire world was a w r and men were dying, loosing
their limbs and eyes.
Chauncey Parker came to dinner last night and we
really kidded him about his farm in Virginia. He will not
admit that it looses money. Appare tly it is one of those a
amazing farms that always break even year in and out. In
other words it looses plenty. His wife told me when I was in
Wasington that it always had lost but now they had a new
manager and expected it to make money. Does this raise old
memories, stories of what manager[s]would do for one. Do you
remember the one at Boone Hall. He was going to set the
world on fire. I heard while I was in the South that not
only had he practically ruined the owners but had threatened
to sue them and had to be bought off. Apparently he had
lost the sight of one eye. The tractor had run over him
or a still had exploded. Whatever it was he claimed it was
due to the owners negligence. No[w]reliable authority tells
me that the original owners are trying to buy it back. Have
you ever heard of anyting so wacky in your life. I am
certain Mo ris is quite right when he says that everyone is
a little bit crazy on some subject. That place has absorbed
more fortunes and its soil has proven a burial ground for
enough money to pay off the national debt. Probably the only
person benefiting from all these deals are the real estate
dealers. However even they do not do so well[,] because the
purchasers and sellers for some re son expect them to do
everyting from the laundry up. I really think that someone
[End Page 1]
placed a curse on the land. Probably one of those haunts
that can only be released if you look at the moon through
corn liker with a rattlesnake between your teeth.
Received a letter from Armant saying that he had
heard from Olive what a wonderful time we had had in New
Orleans and how he wished he had been with us. When we had seen
him last he had said that he would be in New Orleans when we
arrived there. Just joking we said that would arrive long
before he did. The fact that we did has practically broken
his heart. I hope we may see him within the next month.
He is now in charge of a fourteen thousand ton ship, which
is some raise from the days of the Bo Peep and eggs ala Mornay
Bo Peep. Received a letter from a lady asking if we would
sell our little sail boat. I am going to write her that it
is for sale at the same price we paid because I doubt that we
would use it for years. This Jap war will probably go on
for another two years and you will be too busy to go up there.
We may not ever want to go there again, and as this seems to
be a sellers market I believe it is a good time to let it go.
I think this discussion of the reason to sell is very funny
because even if you do receive this letter you probably will
not be able to answer it for months. In fact I cannot
understand why you are not permitted to write. It would help
so much to know that you are alive and well, and I cannot
possibly hee how this information could effect anyone but you
and me.
Bo and Landine sent me christmas cards and Miss
Evans wrote a letter saying that Polly had invited them to
Christmas dinner. She is such a really good friend of yours,
and so kind hearted. Of all the people you have known, familly
and all she is the one who has done the most for the children,
sponsored them and telphoned to find out if they were alright
and needed anything. I wrote youhow kind she was to me
in New York and sent me two bottles of champagne on my
birthday so that I was able to celebrate in great style with
the children and Morris.
Charlie Harding is comming for dinner on Friday.
You may remember that he went with us on that funny fishing
trip with Ruth and Ogden. The one where we all has a poison rash
and I was so hungry all the time that I could think of nothing
but chocolate cream pie. I just spoke to him for a moment so
can not give you any gossip or information on the state of
the world. However I may have something of interest by my
next letter.
Goodbye darling, I do hope you are well, and that
I will hear from you soon. With all my love.
Sidney Legendre
[End Page 2]
